class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Case study: COVID-19 vaccine development</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>The race to develop a COVID-19 vaccine required a massive number of experimental and observational clinical trials. Representation of women was equal to that of men (or better) across trials, but this was not reflected in consistent reporting of sex-specific results. One analysis examined 41 articles on COVID-19 research, of which 35 articles showed safety data, but only 12 of these presented data by sex or gender.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e85e5032-bcde-4945-a61b-9292a2edae95"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e85e5032-bcde-4945-a61b-9292a2edae95" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Amy Vassallo et al., “Sex and gender in COVID-19 vaccine research: Substantial evidence gaps remain,” <em>Frontiers in Global Women’s Health</em>, November 2021, Volume 2.</span></span></span></a></span> In a review of 2,500 COVID-19 studies, less than 5 percent of investigators had planned for sex-disaggregated data analysis in their studies.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="cabf5b9f-c200-43ce-9ed0-6b08102ad38b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="cabf5b9f-c200-43ce-9ed0-6b08102ad38b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Lavanya Vijayasingham et al., “Sex-disaggregated data in COVID-19 vaccine trials,” <em>Lancet</em>, March 2021, Volume 397.</span></span></span></a></span> In studies for which adverse effects and sex differences were published, adverse events were more common in women patients.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="718f4b36-d230-4794-9197-c9d771e472fa"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="718f4b36-d230-4794-9197-c9d771e472fa" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Vassallo et al., “Sex and gender in COVID-19 vaccine research,” November 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>One example of the gap in clinical evaluations can be seen in US clinical trials. The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has issued guidance on gender differences in clinical evaluation of medicines since 1993.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="bf472ec9-1231-435b-be66-e791f28ae461"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">32</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="bf472ec9-1231-435b-be66-e791f28ae461" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">US Food and Drug Administration, “Guideline for the study and evaluation of gender differences in the clinical evaluation of drugs,” <em>Federal Register</em> (58 F.R. 39406), July 1993.</span></span></span></a></span> In clinical trials from 2000 to 2022, women’s participation in oncology trials improved.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="eba774da-d4c7-4280-8f3b-eba3af02fc89"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">33</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="eba774da-d4c7-4280-8f3b-eba3af02fc89" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">K. Jenei et al., “The inclusion of women in global oncology drug trials over the past 20 years,” <em>JAMA Oncology</em>, 2021, Volume 7, Number 10.</span></span></span></a></span> However, a comparison of women’s participation with their share of the disease burden finds that women remain underrepresented in surgical trials for cancers of the bladder, head and neck, stomach, and esophagus.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f95a5372-ad7a-4b56-b0d7-fe22f1c30f52"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">34</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f95a5372-ad7a-4b56-b0d7-fe22f1c30f52" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Nirosha D. Perera et al., “Analysis of female participant representation in registered oncology clinical trials in the United States from 2008 to 2020,” <em>Oncologist</em>, June 2023, Volume 28, Number 6.</span></span></span></a></span> While women experience a greater share of the health burden for some diseases, such as in neurology, the ratio is not reflected in clinical trial participation. Additionally, equitable representation of women (and men) of different races and ethnicities has long lagged (see sidebar “Case study: COVID-19 vaccine development”).</p>
<h3>Ensuring sex-differentiated results</h3>
<p>Representative clinical studies capable of producing stratified results may involve larger and longer clinical trials, increasing costs and extending time to market. However, the results would likely lead to more effective interventions with higher uptake among patients. The risk/reward equation for investors becomes more balanced if payers (governments, insurers, and patients) and regulators insist on evidence for cohort-specific impact.</p>
<p>Today, some conditions, such as leukemia and meningitis, are believed to affect men and women equally. But the research to identify potential differences is lacking. Stakeholders may explore how a systematic and proactive approach to designing and reporting clinical outcomes could take sex and gender into account.</p>
<p>One route to start working with sex- and gender-specific data analysis in general is through meta-analytical techniques—those combining study results to draw conclusions about therapeutic effectiveness. These can be used to analyze sex-specific efficacy without increasing sample size.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5d2e8242-3d4d-45e0-9a2c-1949657bb5e0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">35</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5d2e8242-3d4d-45e0-9a2c-1949657bb5e0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">K. A. L’Abbé, A. S. Detsky, and K. O’Rourke, “Meta-analysis in clinical research,” <em>Annals of Internal Medicine</em>, August 1987, Volume 107, Number 2.</span></span></span></a></span> Other analysis has found that investing in women as investigators could lead to more women enrolled in trials.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="75f00e3d-af71-47ac-97c4-c5224f724f86"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">36</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="75f00e3d-af71-47ac-97c4-c5224f724f86" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Waldhorn et al., “Trends in women’s leadership of oncology clinical trials,” June 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Addressing data gaps in women’s health would require concerted effort across multiple fronts,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7595d0e5-de27-4a74-8a3d-b7e11e685af4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">37</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7595d0e5-de27-4a74-8a3d-b7e11e685af4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">More detailed discussion available in Burns et al., “Closing the data gaps in women’s health,” April 3, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> potentially including requiring sex- and gender-disaggregated data to further understanding.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="dark" data-module-background="deep-blue" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="top-right" class="mck-o-edge-to-edge SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header___N7qG mck-c-module-wrapper"><style></style><div data-component="mdc-c-background-image" class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c background-image-section-header-49C161DDAA454732A57F2E491944F3E7-bg SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__parallax-container__sgMMy" role="img" aria-label="A female doctor performing a mammography test on a young woman in an examination room." style="transform: translate(0px, 0px);"></div><div class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c mdc-c-bg-image--opaque-bg___CauU1_990311c" style="opacity:0.3"></div><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing"><div id="section-header-3" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper__CZEyB"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-positioned__fIWpF"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-sm SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-text__hSx1f" style="display: none; opacity: 0;"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__heading__2ePOu"><span>3. Creating sex- and gender-responsive care delivery systems</span></h2></div><div class="SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__section-holder__BaLti"></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Several studies have indicated that women are more frequent users of health services than men.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c49dbc59-3736-49be-bca9-a9e0c4efce0f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">38</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c49dbc59-3736-49be-bca9-a9e0c4efce0f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">K. D. Bertakis et al., “Gender differences in the utilization of health care services,” <em>Journal of Family Practice</em>, February 2000, Volume 49, Number 2; Gretchen Berlin, Lucia Darino, Megan Greenfield, and Irina Starikova, “<a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/women-in-the-healthcare-industry">Women in the healthcare industry</a>,” McKinsey, June 7, 2019; “Gender mainstreaming in health,” European Institute for Gender Equality (EIGE), January 2017.</span></span></span></a></span> These differences, however, may be reduced substantially when adjusted for different levels of need, such as reproduction or differences in disease prevalence.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="636601c5-e617-46d7-b935-fcfc77a81c25"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">39</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="636601c5-e617-46d7-b935-fcfc77a81c25" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Yingying Wang et al., “Do men consult less than women? An analysis of routinely collected UK general practice data,” <em>BMJ Open</em>, 2013, Volume 3.</span></span></span></a></span> The McKinsey analysis finds that some of this unbalanced usage may result from inadequate service. Compared with men, women who present the same condition may not receive the same evidence-based care.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="796c902d-04d0-4802-8b7f-741348ae8baf"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">40</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="796c902d-04d0-4802-8b7f-741348ae8baf" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Emily Paulsen, “Recognizing, addressing unintended gender bias in patient care,” Duke Health Practice Management, January 14, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> These delays can add unnecessary costs to health systems, not to mention costs and stress to the patient and their family.</p>
<h3>Inequalities exist throughout the full pathway of care</h3>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Intersectionality and health outcomes</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>This paper explores ways in which sex and gender influence an individual’s health chances and experience of health services. These differences are all too often exacerbated by overlapping levels of discrimination and disadvantage, such as race, ethnicity, socioeconomic status, disability, age, and sexual orientation. The effects are strikingly clear in maternal health (exhibit). Within the United States, Native American and Black women are up to four times more likely to die from a pregnancy-related cause than White women. For Black families, this holds true even after adjustment for differences in income levels.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e8191263-0b60-4f3e-943e-8a5219e53f49"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e8191263-0b60-4f3e-943e-8a5219e53f49" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Kate Kennedy-Moulton et al., <em>Maternal and infant health inequality: New evidence from linked administrative data</em>, NBER Working Paper 30093, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> In India, a woman of upper caste is three times more likely to use prenatal care and five times more likely to have a trained birth attendant than a woman of lower caste.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="800406fe-3dfe-4c94-856a-9c5fb03d2333"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="800406fe-3dfe-4c94-856a-9c5fb03d2333" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">E. Saroha, M. Altarac, and L. M. Sibley, “Caste and maternal health care service use among rural Hindu women in Maitha, Uttar Pradesh, India,” <em>Journal of Midwifery & Women's Health</em>, 2008, Volume 53.</span></span></span></a></span> A study in the United Kingdom indicated that women from ethnic minority backgrounds have an increased risk of postpartum hemorrhage.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ee32a55c-7647-451e-a52d-c92f783dc8d8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ee32a55c-7647-451e-a52d-c92f783dc8d8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Jennifer Jardine et al., “Risk of postpartum haemorrhage is associated with ethnicity: A cohort study of 981,801 births in England,” <em>BJOG: An International Journal of Obstetrics and Gynaecology</em>, December 2021, Volume 129, Number 8.</span></span></span></a></span> On a global scale, 94 percent of pregnancy-related deaths occurred in low‐resource settings, with 86 percent occurring in sub‐Saharan Africa and Southern Asia.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="32b63695-12e9-4be1-b01f-7c621f3594ec"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="32b63695-12e9-4be1-b01f-7c621f3594ec" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Maternal health,” Pan American Health Organization, n.d.; <em>Trends in maternal mortality, 2000 to 2017: Estimates by WHO, UNICEF, UNFPA, World Bank Group, and the United Nations Population Division</em>, United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA), September 2019.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit </span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/closing%20the%20womens%20health%20gap%20a%201%20trillion%20dollar%20opportunity%20to%20improve%20lives%20and%20economies/gifs/pub-mhiwomenhealthgap-v16-ex-sidebar-4-lm-timed-v2.gif"><img alt="In the United States, Native American and Black women are two to three times more likely to die from a pregnancy-related cause than White women." src="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/closing%20the%20womens%20health%20gap%20a%201%20trillion%20dollar%20opportunity%20to%20improve%20lives%20and%20economies/gifs/pub-mhiwomenhealthgap-v16-ex-sidebar-4-lm-timed-v2.gif" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The care pathway runs from awareness of a health issue to access to services and preventive care, timely and accurate diagnosis and effective treatment and follow-up. At each segment of this pathway, inequalities exist, especially for women who are disadvantaged in ways beyond their gender (see sidebar “Intersectionality and health outcomes”).</p>
<h4>Awareness and prevention</h4>
<p>Health education, including menstrual education, is one of the most effective ways to help women learn about their bodies.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="044d95fc-3fd8-42d5-96ec-d9b7b748552b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">41</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="044d95fc-3fd8-42d5-96ec-d9b7b748552b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">M. M. Khan, “Menstrual health and hygiene: What role can schools play?,” World Bank, May 27, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Countries vary in the types and amount of health education, but around the world, women who experience conditions such as painful periods, endometriosis, polycystic ovary syndrome, or uterine fibroids may have limited awareness of what is normal and when to seek medical advice.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="08b3b253-a35f-4ec2-8e78-936c906c0af0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">42</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="08b3b253-a35f-4ec2-8e78-936c906c0af0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">F. Ní Chéileachair, B. E. McGuire, and H. Durand, “Coping with dysmenorrhea: A qualitative analysis of period pain management among students who menstruate,” <em>BMC Women’s Health</em>, October 2022, Volume 22, Number 1; A. Jabeen et al., “Polycystic ovarian syndrome: Prevalence, predisposing factors, and awareness among adolescent and young girls of South India,” <em>Cureus</em>, August 2022, Volume 14, Number 8; Chandler Dykstra et al., “‘I think people should be more aware’: Uterine fibroid experiences among women living in Indiana, USA,” <em>Patient Education and Counseling</em>, February 2023, Volume 107.</span></span></span></a></span> Education can also improve school attendance, teach effective management strategies that reduce symptom severity, and reduce potential fertility problems in the future, which are often excluded from health insurance policies.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="27c195d7-cc10-40e1-9d46-4b60ed6308cd"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">43</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="27c195d7-cc10-40e1-9d46-4b60ed6308cd" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Y. T. Yang and D. R. Chen, “Effectiveness of a menstrual health education program on psychological well-being and behavioral change among adolescent girls in rural Uganda,” <em>Journal of Public Health in Africa</em>, April 2023, Volume 14, Number 3; Catherine Kansiime et al., “Menstrual health intervention and school attendance in Uganda (MENISCUS-2): A pilot intervention study,” <em>BMJ Open</em>, 2020, Volume 10, Number 2; Parisa Khalilzadeh et al., “Evaluating the effect of educational intervention based on the health belief model on the lifestyle related to premenstrual syndrome and reduction of its symptoms among the first-grade high school girls,” <em>BMC Public Health</em>, May 2023, Volume 23.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Prevention and promotion are also needed for better health. The human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine, for example, is proven to reduce the incidence of cervical cancer by nearly 90 percent, particularly if women are vaccinated when they are younger.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a1c3a810-d36c-413d-9c56-8d2a12fa53e0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">44</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a1c3a810-d36c-413d-9c56-8d2a12fa53e0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Jiayao Lei et al., “HPV vaccination and the risk of invasive cervical cancer,” <em>New England Journal of Medicine</em>, October 2020, Volume 383.</span></span></span></a></span> In 2020, the WHO launched the 90-70-90 targets, which aim to have 90 percent of girls vaccinated against HPV, 70 percent of women screened for HPV by age 35 and again at 45, and 90 percent of women with precancer treated or with invasive cancer managed. According to the WHO, great disparities exist among countries: less than 25 percent of LICs and less than 30 percent of LMICs have introduced the vaccine, compared with 85 percent of high-income countries (HICs).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="730e3f81-784c-4605-9894-e3c2b6d60109"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">45</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="730e3f81-784c-4605-9894-e3c2b6d60109" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Global strategy to accelerate the elimination of cervical cancer as a public health problem</em>, World Health Organization, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> Some 36 percent of women worldwide have been screened for cervical cancer in their lifetime—84 percent in high-income countries and less than 20 percent in LMICs or LICs.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="752b8783-5c44-4002-80cf-89b7485525a5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">46</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="752b8783-5c44-4002-80cf-89b7485525a5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">L. Bruni et al., “Cervical cancer screening programmes and age-specific coverage estimates for 202 countries and territories worldwide: A review and synthetic analysis,” <em>Lancet Global Health</em>, August 2022, Volume 10, Number 8 (erratum in <em>Lancet Global Health</em>, July 2023, Volume 11, Number 7. In this report, the analysis began with the projected baseline disease burden by sex, age group, year, and country for 195 countries. For more on methodology, see the technical appendix.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>The importance of increasing awareness goes beyond patients. Many doctors are unaware of how diseases can affect or manifest differently in women, so they are unable to provide proper care to many patients.</p>
<h4>Accessibility and affordability of care</h4>
<p>Women may encounter barriers related to access and affordability. Healthcare spending and insurance premiums have historically been higher for women. For instance, in Switzerland, healthcare insurance premiums are more expensive for women because they are considered to have higher healthcare costs. On average, Swiss women pay more than 12 percent extra for supplementary hospital insurance, with greater disparities in specific age groups. A 31-year-old woman pays, on average, 37 percent more than a man of the same age.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2c11a211-45d5-4169-aec1-1889ffcb41c3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">47</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2c11a211-45d5-4169-aec1-1889ffcb41c3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Daniel Dreier, “Financial inequalities between women and men in Switzerland,” Moneyland, January 23, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Similarly, Indian private insurers employ gender-based premiums, leading to higher expenses for women.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="76d5e6e9-88dd-423a-ae44-686345f62a41"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">48</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="76d5e6e9-88dd-423a-ae44-686345f62a41" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“How health insurance premium varies by gender?” Future Generali, February 11, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Further McKinsey analysis of US copay rates finds American women have an average of $135 more out-of-pocket expenses per year than men. Of that, $55 goes to higher copay rates for conditions predominantly affecting women.</p>
<p>Affordability means more than paying for direct healthcare services; it also means being able to afford hygiene products. For instance, around 500 million people worldwide lack access to menstrual products and hygiene facilities.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c16d25bd-bae2-47b3-9869-29a26bcee5f4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">49</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c16d25bd-bae2-47b3-9869-29a26bcee5f4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Menstrual health and hygiene,” World Bank, May 12, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> In Bangladesh, a study conducted by the HERproject showed that 73 percent of women employed by a textile factory in Bangladesh missed work for an average six days a month.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5d467fbb-811b-494b-9037-27491da9a907"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">50</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5d467fbb-811b-494b-9037-27491da9a907" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">K. Tull, “Period poverty impact on the economic empowerment of women,” University of Leeds Nuffield Centre for International Health and Development, January 23, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span> This absenteeism negatively affects not only business but also the lives and the livelihoods of women who are not paid for days they do not work. However, when the HERproject provided menstrual  pads and other work-based interventions (sharing information regarding menstruation, reducing stigma, etcetera), absenteeism dropped to 3 percent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="27be1628-1b22-46c7-a9e7-5591e0d2e694"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">51</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="27be1628-1b22-46c7-a9e7-5591e0d2e694" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">K. Tull, “Period poverty impact on the economic empowerment of women,” University of Leeds Nuffield Centre for International Health and Development, January 23, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Family planning also is highly relevant. Women of childbearing age who are sexually active must evaluate the cost of contraceptives, many of which are not covered by insurance. An estimated 257 million women in developing regions who want to avoid pregnancy are not using safe and effective family-planning methods, for reasons that include a lack of access and support, according to the 2023 Global Contraception Policy Atlas.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4b2a259a-0360-4364-92a0-37d50c30e10a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">52</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4b2a259a-0360-4364-92a0-37d50c30e10a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Launch of the Global Contraception Policy Atlas at Women Deliver 2023,” European Parliamentary Forum for Sexual and Reproductive Rights, July 18, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> For any woman, a lack of contraception—which can lead to sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) or unintended pregnancy—can, in the long run, result in job loss, career setbacks, diminished ability to support oneself or one’s family, and higher levels of “family dysfunction.”<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="33a8cb73-5cbb-4441-ab33-2e38a5244496"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">53</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="33a8cb73-5cbb-4441-ab33-2e38a5244496" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Joseph M. Boden, David M. Fergusson, and l. John Horwood, “Outcomes for children and families following unplanned pregnancy: Findings from a longitudinal birth cohort,” <em>Child Indicators Research</em>, March 2014, Volume 8.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>These disparities can be tackled. Alternative models and systems are helping to increase accessibility and affordability of care for women while also reducing costs for healthcare systems and individuals. Examples include the US Affordable Care Act and women’s health hubs in the United Kingdom.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="95277edf-86f6-4df9-843f-b4c5c1d25b50"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">54</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="95277edf-86f6-4df9-843f-b4c5c1d25b50" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Women’s health hubs cost-benefit analysis,” UK Department of Health & Social Care, July 22, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h4>Timely diagnosis</h4>
<p>The male-centric models of disease described earlier can contribute to delays in care and lower-quality treatment decisions once a woman is within the care system. One study found women were up to seven times more likely than men to have a heart condition misdiagnosed and be discharged during a heart attack.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7ab72e6d-2ec8-4cd6-a7a8-9ad51969d965"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">55</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7ab72e6d-2ec8-4cd6-a7a8-9ad51969d965" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">J. Hector Pope et al., “Missed diagnoses of acute cardiac ischemia in the emergency pepartment,” <em>New England Journal of Medicine</em>, April 2000, Volume 342, Number 16; Elizabeth G. Nabel, “Coronary heart disease in women—an ounce of prevention,” <em>New England Journal of Medicine</em>, August 2000, Volume 343, Number 8; <em>Harvard Health Blog</em>, “Women and pain: Disparities in experience and treatment,” October 9, 2017.</span></span></span></a></span> More sensitive biomarkers to detect heart attacks in women have been identified,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="767df0d3-5e06-40e1-ad6d-feca9fc5aed9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">56</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="767df0d3-5e06-40e1-ad6d-feca9fc5aed9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">O. Ola et al., “Clinical impact of high-sensitivity cardiac troponin T implementation in the community,” <em>Journal of the American College of Cardiology</em>, 2021, Volume 77, Number 25; Arash Mokhtari, Ulf Ekelund, and Ulf Ekström, <em>Riktlinjer för användning av Siemens högkänsliga troponin I vid handläggning av patienter med bröstsmärta</em> (Guidelines for the use of Troponin I (Siemens) in the management of patients with chest pain), Region Skåne (Skåne County, Sweden), November 6, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> and studies are ongoing to validate the impact on health outcomes, but medical school curricula and residency and fellowship trainings need to be updated to reflect these differences.</p>
<p>For maternal care, untreated tuberculosis may have a mortality rate of up to 40 percent in high-risk areas,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6f7692b7-5d71-4c26-a3e4-9d63df7a5a58"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">57</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6f7692b7-5d71-4c26-a3e4-9d63df7a5a58" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">A. Zumla, M. Bates, and P. Mwaba, “The neglected global burden of tuberculosis in pregnancy,” <em>Lancet Global Health</em>, 2014, Volume 2, Number 12.</span></span></span></a></span> where women often have lower uptake of treatment, probably as a result of societal norms. One possible solution is the integration of tuberculosis screening in antenatal care for pregnant women. This strategy was tested in Pakistan and proved to be feasible and effective.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e1ff7e89-768e-465e-b532-14d1a736a737"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">58</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e1ff7e89-768e-465e-b532-14d1a736a737" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Rozina Feroz Ali et al., “Integrating tuberculosis screening into antenatal visits to improve tuberculosis diagnosis and care: Results from a pilot project in Pakistan,” <em>International Journal of Infectious Diseases</em>, July 2021, Volume 108.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h4>Choice of treatment</h4>
<p>Accurate diagnosis should prompt delivery of evidence-based treatment. But sex and gender can affect care, even for common conditions. For example, upon discharge, women cardiac patients are less likely to be prescribed secondary prevention to reduce the risk of further events. This (along with other risk factors) contributes to women being twice as likely to die from a serious heart attack.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="71cad3da-50b8-4c9f-9488-f64b2eb49a33"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">59</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="71cad3da-50b8-4c9f-9488-f64b2eb49a33" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Women more likely to die after heart attack than men,” press release, European Society of Cardiology, May 22, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Outcomes after an acute cardiac event could potentially improve via sex- and gender-adapted protocols for guideline-directed management. This begins at admission and continues through the procedure and until discharge. One health system reduced outcome disparities with a standardized systemwide protocol that includes emergency department catheterization lab activation, a STEMI (ST elevation myocardial infarction) safe-handoff checklist; transfer to an immediately available catheterization lab, and a radial-first approach to percutaneous coronary intervention.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e00ab620-0cbc-4d29-b8d8-0e00f1687362"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">60</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e00ab620-0cbc-4d29-b8d8-0e00f1687362" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">C. P. Huded et al., “4-step protocol for disparities in STEMI care and outcomes in women,” <em>Journal of the American College of Cardiology</em>, 2018, Volume 71, Number 19.</span></span></span></a></span> A discharge checklist for guideline-directed medical therapy has been shown to reduce mortality in heart failure patients by 65 percent for both sexes.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5520dc23-851e-4c73-8fb2-6fff62c81de3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">61</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5520dc23-851e-4c73-8fb2-6fff62c81de3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">H. Rismiati et al., “The role of discharge checklist in guideline-directed medical therapy for heart failure patients,” <em>Korean Journal of Internal Medicine</em>, 2023, Volume 38, Number 2.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>While some efforts to achieve gender parity require heavy investment, there are budget-conscious solutions with potentially huge impact. UNICEF’s Côte d’Ivoire Country Office, for example, produced a low-cost version of a uterine balloon tamponade device to treat maternal hemorrhage. The product, which uses a catheter and a condom, has a 95 percent success rate and has been scaled nationally.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4a6485cf-5ec4-4aaa-81ec-797f92b7f9d5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">62</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4a6485cf-5ec4-4aaa-81ec-797f92b7f9d5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Uterine balloon tamponade,” UNICEF Office of Innovation, n.d.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h3>Creating solutions to tackle care disparities</h3>
<p>Overall, the gap in care delivery contributes 34 percent to the women’s health gap (see Exhibit 1 above). Consider how sex- and gender-appropriate care delivery could reduce the women’s health burden by 25 million DALYs per year globally, corresponding to 2.5 days per woman per year.</p>
<p>Global public health programs are increasingly being designed and improved from a sex- and gender-informed perspective. This involves an investigation of the role sex and gender play in health outcomes, including health-related stigma, barriers to accessing health services, and vulnerabilities to different health risks. For example, the Stop TB Partnership developed a gender-responsive tuberculosis delivery program and associated investment package.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="cb3437fd-dde0-42b7-9cca-33d1be42d70d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">63</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="cb3437fd-dde0-42b7-9cca-33d1be42d70d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Gender and TB: A Stop TB Partnership paper, </em>Stop TB Partnership, 2021<em>; Gender and TB investment package: Community, rights and gender</em>, Stop TB Partnership, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> One pillar of this approach is the routine collection, analysis, and use of sex-disaggregated data and inclusion of sex and gender in monitoring and evaluation.</p>
<p>Improvements in the diagnostic tools available would represent a major step forward for patients. Yet even without innovative tools, it would be possible to improve care and bridge the gaps in diagnosis with more consistent and standardized screening and data collection. Earlier diagnosis and a more holistic, patient-centric treatment approach could help improve disease and symptom management, prevent uncontrolled progression and resulting complications, and reduce unnecessary treatments.</p>
<p>When it comes to affordability and access, counteracting the rise in healthcare costs while benefiting patients and insurance providers could be achieved through approaches such as value-based care (VBC). VBC aims to link healthcare payments to the quality of outcomes, shifting incentives for healthcare providers from performing more treatments to delivering better treatments. These models seek to enhance care quality and reduce healthcare expenses by emphasizing prevention and high-quality results.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="34647e07-455d-4ec2-b158-d42a16c2e4fc"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">64</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="34647e07-455d-4ec2-b158-d42a16c2e4fc" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“‘What is CMMI?’ and 11 other FAQs about the CMS Innovation Center,” KFF, 2018.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>VBC models in the United States include accountable care organizations (ACOs), voluntary networks of healthcare providers operating under Medicare. This includes the Medicare Shared Savings Program (MSSP), which returned $1.9 billion in net savings to Medicare in 2020.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f283254f-a1e4-45cb-8129-cc684ae1669a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">65</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f283254f-a1e4-45cb-8129-cc684ae1669a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Medicare Shared Savings Program saves Medicare more than $1.8 billion in 2022, continues to deliver high-quality care,” news release,  US Department of Health and Human Services, August 24, 2023; Corinne Lewis et al., “The impact of the payment and delivery system reforms of the Affordable Care Act,” Commonwealth Fund, April 28, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Outside of the United States, the European Hospital Alliance’s nine hospitals have offered a blueprint that includes measuring costs and outcomes for every patient and bundled payments for care cycles.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a1703897-8cbb-49c6-83b8-79a77c456bfb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">66</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a1703897-8cbb-49c6-83b8-79a77c456bfb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Y. Cossio-Gil et al., “The roadmap for implementing value-based healthcare in European university hospitals—consensus report and recommendations,” <em>Value in Health</em>, 2022, Volume 25, Number 7.</span></span></span></a></span> Value-based models are designed to reduce costs while improving quality outcomes for patients. For example, given the amount of time, number of tests, and number of providers a woman may see before an endometriosis diagnosis, a revised model of care could offer a holistic and patient-centric approach that provides a faster diagnosis, reduces costs for a healthcare system or payer, and ultimately improves outcomes.</p>
<p>At a global level, AI, unbiased data sets, and interoperable electronic records are potential options for enhancing care delivery. Ultimately, a combination of innovation, investment, and ability to scale could unlock better care delivery solutions for women.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="dark" data-module-background="deep-blue" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="top-right" class="mck-o-edge-to-edge SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header___N7qG mck-c-module-wrapper"><style></style><div data-component="mdc-c-background-image" class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c background-image-section-header-DD2EAB2425D5416180CEFD5BF85E054C-bg SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__parallax-container__sgMMy" role="img" aria-label="A young mother efficiently managing her household finances using a laptop while tenderly caring for her baby seated on her lap." style="transform: translate(0px, 0px);"></div><div class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c mdc-c-bg-image--opaque-bg___CauU1_990311c" style="opacity:0.1"></div><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing"><div id="section-header-4" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper__CZEyB"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-positioned__fIWpF"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-sm SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-text__hSx1f" style="display: none; opacity: 0;"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__heading__2ePOu"><span>4. Directing investments toward women’s health</span></h2></div><div class="SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__section-holder__BaLti"></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>There has been a historical underinvestment in women’s health research from the public, social, and private sectors. Funding sources typically overlook the fact that many conditions manifest differently in each sex, creating variances in outcome.</p>
<p>Closing the health gap will require increased investment not only for understanding sex-based differences but also for addressing unmet needs in women’s health. Further, additional funding and new business models could support sex- and gender-appropriate care.</p>
<h3>Research funding neglects women’s health</h3>
<p>One approach to redirecting investments is to examine policies based on actual population needs. This approach is pertinent for public funding, which continues to be one of the primary investment sources for scientific research. In the United States, up to 45 percent of basic and applied life-sciences research is funded through federal and nonfederal government sources.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e46ff521-230f-4707-8dfe-12340e520164"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">67</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e46ff521-230f-4707-8dfe-12340e520164" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>U.S. research and development funding and performance: Fact sheet</em>, Congressional Research Service, September 13, 2022; Mark Boroush and Ledia Guci, “Research and development: US trends and international comparisons,” Science and Engineering Indicators, National Science Board, April 28, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> The importance of public funding is even higher if we consider that for life sciences companies to reach later-stage development, they rely on results from basic and applied research.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0f16c2f5-d032-4238-9fe5-1f451ceda3e2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">68</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0f16c2f5-d032-4238-9fe5-1f451ceda3e2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">E. Cleary, M. J. Jackson, and F. Ledley, “Government as the first investor in biopharmaceutical innovation: Evidence from new drug approvals 2010–2019.” Institute for New Economic Thinking Working Paper Series No. 133, November 18, 2020; E. G. Cleary et al., “Contribution of NIH funding to new drug approvals 2010–2016,” <em>Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America</em>, 2018, Volume 115, Number 10.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Women’s health funding data by country can be scarce. In the United States, the National Institutes of Health (NIH) allocates 11 percent of its budget to women’s-health-specific research. Thus, despite women having a 50 percent higher mortality rate in the year following a heart attack, only 4.5 percent of the NIH’s budget for coronary artery disease supports women-focused research.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1cc896c8-58e8-4bc8-a8a0-829c37ca15a3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">69</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1cc896c8-58e8-4bc8-a8a0-829c37ca15a3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Perspectives on advancing NIH research to inform and improve the health of women</em>, National Institutes of Health, Office of Research on Women’s Health, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> In Canada and the United Kingdom, 5.9 percent of grants between 2009 and 2020 went to research that looked at female-specific outcomes or women’s health.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="769c72a3-8422-4a3b-9600-2eb91903a539"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">70</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="769c72a3-8422-4a3b-9600-2eb91903a539" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">K. Smith, “Women’s health research lacks funding—these charts show how,” <em>Nature</em>, May 3, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>In another example as of 2015, there were five times more scientific studies on erectile dysfunction than premenstrual syndrome.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="71b981fe-f150-44f3-a335-7855710e46eb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">71</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="71b981fe-f150-44f3-a335-7855710e46eb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">ResearchGate Blog, “Why do we still not know what causes PMS?,” August 12, 2016.</span></span></span></a></span> In a trial where the medication sildenafil citrate was shown to relieve menstrual pain, research stopped due to a lack of funding.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2ff7d06f-626f-43fd-b4be-fc13e0dc1692"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">72</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2ff7d06f-626f-43fd-b4be-fc13e0dc1692" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">R. Dmitrovic, A. R. Kunselman, and R. S. Legro, “Sildenafil citrate in the treatment of pain in primary dysmenorrhea: A randomized controlled trial,” <em>Human Reproduction</em>, November 2013, Volume 28, Number 11; “There’s a gender gap in medical data, and it’s costing women their lives, says this author,” CBC, August 17, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>These examples reflect how underfunding certain research leads to and augments the women’s health gap. One goal could be for existing budgets to be more fairly distributed to reflect the disease burden and unmet need. When governments and nonprofits evaluate resources and policies across populations, they create an opportunity to advance health equity and benefit society. They could consider which investments reap the highest socioeconomic return, including in medical research. One example of targeted investment is the 3not30 campaign by Women’s Health Access Matters, which aims to increase women’s health research and accelerate investment in sex-based research over the next three years.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d56353b3-dd30-4827-b286-c1ce3829511d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">73</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d56353b3-dd30-4827-b286-c1ce3829511d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“WHAM launches #3not30 Campaign to call for doubling the funding for women’s health research in the next three years,” news release, Women’s Health Access Matters (WHAM), January 19, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Many attractive opportunities in women’s health remain untapped. Currently, global life sciences R&D efforts primarily focus on conditions with a high contribution of years of life lost (YLLs) to the overall disability-adjusted life years (DALY). This has often disadvantaged women since they have a higher probability of being affected by conditions that affect quality of life—measured as years lived with a disability (YLDs)—rather than length of life. Among these conditions are rheumatoid arthritis, endometriosis, uterine fibroids, and diabetes. The disability weight for someone with moderate abdominal pain and primary infertility due to endometriosis is 0.121; for moderate rheumatoid arthritis, it is 0.3017. This translates to a person being willing to trade a year of their life to avoid 8.3 years of living with endometriosis or to trade a year of life to avoid 3.2 years with rheumatoid arthritis. Additionally, gynecological conditions, such as endometriosis and uterine fibroids, which affect up to 68 percent of women,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9d52d455-e11f-44bd-acbe-841cf540321f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">74</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9d52d455-e11f-44bd-acbe-841cf540321f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Zheng Lou et al., “Global, regional, and national time trends in incidence, prevalence, years lived with disability for uterine fibroids, 1990–2019: An age-period-cohort analysis for the Global Burden of Disease 2019 study,” <em>BMC Public Health</em>, May 2023, Volume 23, Number 916.</span></span></span></a></span> have 33 assets in the pipeline , while other conditions that affect a lower percentage have more assets (Exhibit 8).</p>

their quality of life. </p></div></div></div></div><div class="DefaultScrolly_mck-c-default-scrolly__content-text__lFvee mck-c-default-scrolly__content-text--three-columns text-content-8B7D3333057E4436BCA0F5E8D2878AAD" data-id="EE84BC22607B4D01AE2C83CB90233384" data-react-scrollama-id="react-scrollama-1" entry="[object IntersectionObserverEntry]"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"></h2><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline"><div><p>Some conditions, such as colon or liver cancer, affect men and women differently, and on average, women are more likely to develop a more serious or severe form of these conditions.</p></div></div></div></div><div class="DefaultScrolly_mck-c-default-scrolly__content-text__lFvee mck-c-default-scrolly__content-text--three-columns text-content-8B7D3333057E4436BCA0F5E8D2878AAD" data-id="EC69149D897245F09224C8A376324EB7" data-react-scrollama-id="react-scrollama-2" entry="[object IntersectionObserverEntry]"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"></h2><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline"><div><p>Certain conditions, such as Alzheimer’s and other dementias, affect women disproportionately. A 2019 report found that, globally, women with dementia outnumbered men with dementia 100 to 69.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="662f97d2-9568-4408-8348-00abeb799e08"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="662f97d2-9568-4408-8348-00abeb799e08" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">GBD 2019 Dementia Forecasting Collaborators, “Estimation of the global prevalence of dementia in 2019 and forecasted prevalence in 2050: An analysis for the Global Burden of Disease Study 2019,” <em>Lancet Public Health</em>, February 2022, Volume 7, Issue 2.</span></span></span></a></span></p></div></div></div></div><div class="DefaultScrolly_mck-c-default-scrolly__content-text__lFvee mck-c-default-scrolly__content-text--three-columns text-content-8B7D3333057E4436BCA0F5E8D2878AAD" data-id="08AF3F685CB8499AB8105AADEBDA7652" data-react-scrollama-id="react-scrollama-3" entry="[object IntersectionObserverEntry]"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"></h2><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline"><div><p>Certain women-specific conditions, such as ovarian cancer, cause less disability because the fatality rates are higher. Ovarian cancer is the most lethal gynecological cancer, with a five-year relative survival rate of 17 percent for a patient diagnosed at an advanced stage.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ff328e09-12b6-4496-910c-4048ca18611f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ff328e09-12b6-4496-910c-4048ca18611f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Lauren A. Baldwin et al., “Ten-year relative survival for epithelial ovarian cancer,” <em>Obstetrics & Gynecology</em>, September 2012, Volume 120, Number 3.</span></span></span></a></span></p></div></div></div></div><div class="DefaultScrolly_mck-c-default-scrolly__content-text__lFvee mck-c-default-scrolly__content-text--three-columns assets and share of suffering caused by disability.</p></div></div></div></div><div class="DefaultScrolly_mck-c-default-scrolly__content-text__lFvee mck-c-default-scrolly__content-text--three-columns
