class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Market potential of treatments for endometriosis and menopause</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>Globally, 190 million women are suffering from endometriosis.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1ab0875d-7efe-4a52-9e2d-b23372254d0c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1ab0875d-7efe-4a52-9e2d-b23372254d0c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Endometriosis,” World Health Organization, March 24, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Currently, no cure exists, and treatments focus on symptom management. Based on prevalence and unmet need, the market potential for endometriosis treatments is estimated at $180 billion to $250 billion globally (exhibit), given today’s share of endometriosis patients seeking treatment. Innovation in this space, including faster diagnosis rates and earlier access to treatment, could increase the market potential.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit </span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/closing%20the%20womens%20health%20gap%20a%201%20trillion%20dollar%20opportunity%20to%20improve%20lives%20and%20economies/gifs/pub-mhiwomenhealthgap-v16-ex-sidebar-5-lm-timed-v2.gif"><img alt="Endometriosis and menopause have high market potential because of disease prevalence and unmet need." src="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/closing%20the%20womens%20health%20gap%20a%201%20trillion%20dollar%20opportunity%20to%20improve%20lives%20and%20economies/gifs/pub-mhiwomenhealthgap-v16-ex-sidebar-5-lm-timed-v2.gif" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Menopause is another area of high unmet need globally. Based on the age distribution of the population and share of symptomatic cases, it is estimated that more than 450 million women worldwide have menopausal or perimenopausal symptoms.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="26ff3c30-10df-40ba-8019-e77880d33219"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="26ff3c30-10df-40ba-8019-e77880d33219" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Estimate based on global population of women between ages 45 and 55 and more than 90 percent of women experiencing at least one symptom during the menopausal transition.</span></span></span></a></span> Based on the prevalence of menopause, its impact on women’s life, the high unmet need, and the share of women seeking treatment today, estimated global market potential to treat symptoms ranges from $120 billion to $350 billion globally.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="72f8823f-dc12-4fa1-8a19-5bb6d88f805f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="72f8823f-dc12-4fa1-8a19-5bb6d88f805f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Aja Mangum, “The $600 billion market for women in menopause is fit for disruption,” Bloomberg, March 28, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Addressing sex-specific conditions can pay off. For example, the debut of Viagra for erectile dysfunction, which affected an estimated 152 million men in 1995, generated $400 million in sales revenue within its first three months in the US market in 1998.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="40fb10d9-3fa8-4e9d-9725-87cad2e2909c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">75</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="40fb10d9-3fa8-4e9d-9725-87cad2e2909c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">I. A. Ayta, J. B. McKinlay, and R. J. Krane, “The likely worldwide increase in erectile dysfunction between 1995 and 2025 and some possible policy consequences,” <em>BJU International</em>, July 1999, Volume 84, Number 1; Berkeley Lovelace Jr., “Pfizer still holds the lead in the erectile dysfunction market even as Viagra sales falter,” CNBC, February 14, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span> By 2012, worldwide sales hit a record $2.1 billion.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f66434be-549f-4982-85e1-4d43baaef8d8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">76</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f66434be-549f-4982-85e1-4d43baaef8d8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Viagra outdoes competition with Q3 sales,” <em>Pharmaceutical Technology</em>, December 18, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> Globally, given the similar prevalence and high unmet need for conditions such as endometriosis and menopause, there is enormous potential for innovative treatments (see sidebar “Market potential of treatments for endometriosis and menopause”).</p>
<p>Enormous potential also exists for treatment of breast cancer. There is high interest in breast cancer R&D (646 assets in the pipeline), and sales revenues from breast cancer treatments were at $18 billion in 2022 (comparatively, sales for prostate cancer treatments were $11 billion in 2022).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fa68f4b0-67f3-40da-8be3-a6fea79524a1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">77</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fa68f4b0-67f3-40da-8be3-a6fea79524a1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Evaluate Pharma database, accessed 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> An opportunity remains to improve outcomes of breast cancer in LMICs, where the fatality rate of 72 percent has been higher than the incidence rate (62 percent).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2a887f32-340d-4bfd-86e0-d796a0a13215"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">78</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2a887f32-340d-4bfd-86e0-d796a0a13215" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">S. Al-Sukhun et al., “Breast cancer priorities in limited-resource environments: The price-efficacy dilemma in cancer care,” <em>American Society of Clinical Oncology Educational Book</em>, Volume 42, June 22, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Globally, endometriosis, uterine fibroids and menopause are among the conditions with high unmet need and economic potential.</p>
<h3>Private equity/venture capital investors are increasing investments in women’s health, with excitement about digital health solutions</h3>
<p>Private equity and venture capital investments in women’s health are starting to grow quickly as opportunities in women’s health become clearer and more female technology (FemTech) start-ups set out to disrupt the healthcare market.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="836809e4-8987-416c-a995-54eec84ffc37"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">79</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="836809e4-8987-416c-a995-54eec84ffc37" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">E. Kemble et al., “<a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/the-dawn-of-the-femtech-revolution">The dawn of the FemTech revolution</a>,” McKinsey, February 14, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Within the FemTech space is concentrated activity concerning maternal health patient support, consumer menstrual products, gynecological devices, and fertility solutions.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="68370b86-dfd6-4d6d-8529-933cbb780028"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">80</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="68370b86-dfd6-4d6d-8529-933cbb780028" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">E. Kemble et al., “<a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/the-dawn-of-the-femtech-revolution">The dawn of the FemTech revolution</a>,” McKinsey, February 14, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>The start-ups making the top deals in the past four years mainly focus on men’s sexual and overall health. A McKinsey analysis found that 11 start-ups addressing erectile dysfunction, among other men’s health concerns, secured $1.24 billion in 2019–23, while eight start-ups addressing endometriosis received $44 million. Funding for companies focusing on erectile dysfunction was six times greater than for companies focused on endometriosis. However, investors may be starting to see the potential. In the past four years, women’s health newcomers received $2.2 billion in funding. Some 60 percent of the top deals exclusively addressed women’s health, specifically endometriosis, fertility, and maternal and neonatal health.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="62e0c7ff-12bf-4125-bc3f-c707bf61f31c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">81</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="62e0c7ff-12bf-4125-bc3f-c707bf61f31c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">E. Kemble et al., “<a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/the-dawn-of-the-femtech-revolution">The dawn of the FemTech revolution</a>,” McKinsey, February 14, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Another potential avenue for innovation is digital health, which has the potential to make health more equitable.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="35167349-daae-44a5-aa63-ae901a6262c3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">82</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="35167349-daae-44a5-aa63-ae901a6262c3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">D. Argyres et al., “<a href="/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/digital-health-an-opportunity-to-advance-health-equity">Digital health: An opportunity to advance health equity</a>,” McKinsey, July 26, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> In the digital healthcare space, FemTech companies received 3 percent of the total digital-health funding.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="687da454-11c4-4e08-85f1-1a5f6dd7e3e4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">83</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="687da454-11c4-4e08-85f1-1a5f6dd7e3e4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“FemTech Revolution: Which start-ups are transforming women’s health?,” EIT Health Ireland-UK, March 8, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Given the large unmet need and resulting opportunity, those who continue to forgo investing in women’s health may find themselves left behind by the players that tap into this high-potential market.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="dark" data-module-background="deep-blue" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="top-right" class="mck-o-edge-to-edge SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header___N7qG mck-c-module-wrapper"><style></style><div data-component="mdc-c-background-image" class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c background-image-section-header-4F78A6FEC0BC4BE99F5D29D219322F4B-bg SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__parallax-container__sgMMy" role="img" aria-label="A confident female leader leading an all-female team meeting." style="transform: translate(0px, 0px);"></div><div class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c mdc-c-bg-image--opaque-bg___CauU1_990311c" style="opacity:0.3"></div><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing"><div id="section-header-5" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper__CZEyB"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-positioned__fIWpF"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-sm SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-text__hSx1f" style="display: none; opacity: 0;"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__heading__2ePOu"><span>5. Closing the gap in women’s health could boost the global economy</span></h2></div><div class="SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__section-holder__BaLti"></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The disparities in women’s health affect not only women’s quality of life but also their economic participation and ability to earn a living for themselves and their families. Health is intricately linked to economic productivity, prospects for prosperity, and contribution to economic output. Economic growth over the past 70 years has been closely tied to women’s increased labor force participation. Therefore, it is not surprising that the gap in women’s health results in lost economic potential.</p>
<p>Addressing the health gap women face could boost the global economy by adding at least $1 trillion to the global economy by 2040. This means a 1.7 percent increase in the average per capita GDP generated by women.</p>
<h3>Women’s economic participation has been and will be a major driver of economic growth</h3>
<p>Extended participation by women boosts economies and GDP growth.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="04b7444f-f018-42bb-b511-cacd2339985b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">84</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="04b7444f-f018-42bb-b511-cacd2339985b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">E. Ortiz-Ospina, S. Tzvetkova, and M. Roser, “Women’s employment,” <em>Our World in Data</em>, 2018.</span></span></span></a></span> The rise in the number of women in formal economic activities since the 1950s has been a major driver of economic growth and wage increases.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7e50a944-b88e-4390-adea-4022ffcf8e5a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">85</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7e50a944-b88e-4390-adea-4022ffcf8e5a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">A. Weinstein, “When more women join the workforce, wages rise—including for men,” <em>Harvard Business Review</em>, January 31, 2018.</span></span></span></a></span> Ability to participate in the economy also benefits women individually. In a 2023 poll, when women around the world were asked if they preferred to work in paid jobs, care for their families, or do both, 70 percent said they preferred to work in paid jobs or do both.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d04c14a1-a5b2-4772-b537-f3872cd36834"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">86</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d04c14a1-a5b2-4772-b537-f3872cd36834" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">That is, the 70 percent combines responses from women saying they would prefer to work at paid jobs with responses from those saying they prefer to both work at paid jobs and care for their homes and families. <em>Towards a better future for women and work: Voices of women and men</em>, International Labour Organization/Gallup, 2017.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Endometriosis and menopause have a substantial impact on women’s ability to work and earning potential</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>Menopause and endometriosis not only cause women pain and reduce their quality of life but also substantially affect their ability to work and their earning potential. Roughly 80 percent of affected women state that menopause interferes with their lives, and one-third of these women also experience depression.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4afedb8c-02c7-4568-b853-96c3ec2b55e7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4afedb8c-02c7-4568-b853-96c3ec2b55e7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Burns et al., “Closing the data gaps in women’s health,” April 3, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Further, menopause is linked to premature departure from the workforce.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6e9af389-6f0c-49ee-8399-54200534a2a8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6e9af389-6f0c-49ee-8399-54200534a2a8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Lizzy Burden, “Women are leaving the workforce for a little-talked-about reason,” Bloomberg, June 18, 2021; S. D’Angelo et al., “Impact of menopausal symptoms on work: Findings from women in the Health and Employment after Fifty (HEAF) study,” <em>International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health</em>, December 2022, Volume 20, Number 1.</span></span></span></a></span> Similarly, endometriosis is linked to loss in productivity and absenteeism.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="da4b19cd-d136-4436-b1d3-83fa32e354d1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="da4b19cd-d136-4436-b1d3-83fa32e354d1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Kelechi E. Nnoaham et al., “Impact of endometriosis on quality of life and work productivity: A multicenter study across ten countries,” <em>Fertility and Sterility</em>, August 2011, Volume 96, Number 2.</span></span></span></a></span> This analysis factors in the actual economic impact for both conditions. Studies have found that up to 90 percent of women reported menopausal symptoms during the transition.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="543ddd93-a077-4f62-9f28-b52523fe65c3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="543ddd93-a077-4f62-9f28-b52523fe65c3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Ginger D. Constantine et al., “Behaviours and attitudes influencing treatment decisions for menopausal symptoms in five European countries,” <em>Post Reproductive Health</em>, September 2016, Volume 22, Number 3.
    </span></span></span></a></span> This leads to a global prevalence of more than 450 million women and highlights the vast underestimate (versus 35 million in the IHME database). For endometriosis, IHME places the number of cases at 24 million, whereas the WHO puts the prevalence at 190 million.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d40124df-0db1-4b13-8156-ce09ac1ef4aa"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d40124df-0db1-4b13-8156-ce09ac1ef4aa" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">WHO, “Endometriosis,” March 24, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Based on these adjusted numbers, improving effectiveness, uptake, access, and delivery of care for these conditions alone could give a $130 billion uplift to the global economy by 2040 (exhibit).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit </span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/closing%20the%20womens%20health%20gap%20a%201%20trillion%20dollar%20opportunity%20to%20improve%20lives%20and%20economies/gifs/pub-mhiwomenhealthgap-v16-ex-sidebar-6-lm-timed-v2.gif"><img alt="Addressing endometriosis and menopause could boost global GDP by $130 billion." src="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/closing%20the%20womens%20health%20gap%20a%201%20trillion%20dollar%20opportunity%20to%20improve%20lives%20and%20economies/gifs/pub-mhiwomenhealthgap-v16-ex-sidebar-6-lm-timed-v2.gif" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Conversely, the women’s health gap limits individual women and directly affects the global economy by impairing women’s economic participation and productivity. Chronic diseases are often linked to extended absences from work,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2aa62382-379c-4c04-b148-a76209574849"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">87</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2aa62382-379c-4c04-b148-a76209574849" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Paul Hemp, “Presenteeism: At work—but out of it,” <em>Harvard Business Review</em>, October 2004.</span></span></span></a></span> and poor health is a cause of “presenteeism,” where individuals go to work but cannot perform at their full capacity, reducing productivity. Finally, disabilities and informal caregiving obligations hold back affected individuals, often women, from full workforce participation (see sidebar “Endometriosis and menopause have a substantial impact on women’s ability to work and earning potential”).</p>
<p>Addressing the gap could generate the equivalent impact of 137 million women accessing full-time positions by 2040. This would enable women to secure an income to support themselves and their families and has the potential to lift more women out of poverty.</p>
<h4>Better health often enables individuals to work more effectively</h4>
<p>The health disparities outlined in this report affect individuals of all age groups, with about 50 percent of the burden affecting women of working age. Closing the women’s health gap could allow women to add 1.7 percent to GDP . Comparatively, the World Bank estimates that if the status quo remained, GDP growth could reach 2.7 percent, 2.9 percent, and 3.4 percent in 2023, 2024, and 2025, respectively.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fb08d52e-0ae5-43d8-9d8e-4578ede93a9b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">88</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fb08d52e-0ae5-43d8-9d8e-4578ede93a9b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Global economic prospects</em>, World Bank, June 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Looking at the different channels affecting GDP, the largest impact, amounting to around $400 billion or avoiding 24 million years with disability, would be created through fewer health conditions (Exhibit 9). Expanded participation and increased productivity could each contribute more than 20 percent of total impact.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 9</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/closing%20the%20womens%20health%20gap%20a%201%20trillion%20dollar%20opportunity%20to%20improve%20lives%20and%20economies/gifs/pub-mhiwomenhealthgap-v16-ex10-lm-timed.gif"><img alt="Global GDP could rise by $1 trillion by closing the gender gap in healthcare, boosting GDP annual growth until 2040 by four basis points." src="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/closing%20the%20womens%20health%20gap%20a%201%20trillion%20dollar%20opportunity%20to%20improve%20lives%20and%20economies/gifs/pub-mhiwomenhealthgap-v16-ex10-lm-timed.gif" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h4>Treating ten health conditions would contribute more than half of the economic impact</h4>
<p>On a global level, effective treatment of ten conditions—for example, premenstrual syndrome (PMS), depressive symptoms, and migraines—could make up more than 50 percent of the economic impact (Exhibit 10). This impact suggests which conditions to consider prioritizing globally. For example, addressing PMS has the potential to contribute $115 billion to the global economy. Rather than defaulting to PMS being a “part of life,” there are ways to manage symptoms. A 2020 analysis found that women who took calcium supplements experienced fewer PMS symptoms, such as anxiety or water retention, than women who took a placebo.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="64e521dc-1784-42d1-b170-4819ff101a0d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">89</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="64e521dc-1784-42d1-b170-4819ff101a0d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Arman Arab et al., “Beneficial role of calcium in premenstrual syndrome: A systematic review of current literature,” <em>International Journal of Preventive Medicine</em>, September 2020, Volume 11.</span></span></span></a></span> A study in Iran found that the severity and frequency of PMS symptoms was significantly lower in an intervention group that offered education and coping strategies.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ea31051c-e4a4-4fb5-9ecb-429cf2e36789"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">90</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ea31051c-e4a4-4fb5-9ecb-429cf2e36789" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Farzaneh Babapour et al., “The effect of peer education compared to education provided by healthcare providers on premenstrual syndrome in high school students: A social network‐based quasi‐experimental controlled trial,” <em>Neuropsychopharmacology Reports</em>, March 2023, Volume 43, Number 1.</span></span></span></a></span> Addressing PMS with effective interventions could allow women to experience less pain, experience better quality of life, and feel more able to work.</p>
<p>The conditions having the greatest economic impact in different countries will differ from one geographic region to another based on each region’s disease burden and healthcare status. The examination of economic impact, rather than DALY impact, gives more weight to conditions that affect people during years of working age, as that is when economic contribution is highest. Conditions such as ischemic heart disease may affect more people, but if the burden of morbidity and premature mortality happens after the usual age of retirement, the economic impact is more limited.</p>
<p>Additionally, other conditions not listed could be the underlying cause for the top ten conditions. For example, infertility can lead to significant anxiety, depression symptoms, and other psychological distress.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="119193d0-2b3a-44b6-8722-210249f8bb44"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">91</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="119193d0-2b3a-44b6-8722-210249f8bb44" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Cedars-Sinai Blog, “How infertility impacts mental health,” September 8, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 10</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/closing%20the%20womens%20health%20gap%20a%201%20trillion%20dollar%20opportunity%20to%20improve%20lives%20and%20economies/gifs/pub-mhiwomenhealthgap-v16-ex11-lm-timed.gif"><img alt="Ten conditions would contribute more than 50 percent of the total GDP impact related to closing the gap in women’s health." src="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/closing%20the%20womens%20health%20gap%20a%201%20trillion%20dollar%20opportunity%20to%20improve%20lives%20and%20economies/gifs/pub-mhiwomenhealthgap-v16-ex11-lm-timed.gif" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Generally, a reduction in health conditions is tied to a woman’s economic potential, with allowances for regional socioeconomic and healthcare factors (Exhibit 11). The top two conditions by contribution to GDP impact of the women’s health gap are always a combination of two of the top four global conditions: PMS, depression, migraine, or other gynecological conditions. Larger differences among regions are observed when looking at the top ten or more conditions.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 11</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/closing%20the%20womens%20health%20gap%20a%201%20trillion%20dollar%20opportunity%20to%20improve%20lives%20and%20economies/gifs/pub-mhiwomenhealthgap-v16-ex12-lm-timed.gif"><img alt="The impact of closing the gender gap primarily results from a decline in the number of health conditions across different geographies." src="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/closing%20the%20womens%20health%20gap%20a%201%20trillion%20dollar%20opportunity%20to%20improve%20lives%20and%20economies/gifs/pub-mhiwomenhealthgap-v16-ex12-lm-timed.gif" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Across the four channels, the highest GDP impact relative to women’s GDP is observed in HICs and LICs (Exhibit 12). For LICs, most of the impact comes from fewer early deaths and fewer health conditions. Both upper-middle-income (UMIC) and lower-middle-income (LMIC) regions exhibit an overall lower projected GDP impact.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 12</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/closing%20the%20womens%20health%20gap%20a%201%20trillion%20dollar%20opportunity%20to%20improve%20lives%20and%20economies/gifs/pub-mhiwomenhealthgap-v16-ex13-lm-timed.gif"><img alt="Fewer health conditions for women would create the most impact related to GDP across countries." src="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/closing%20the%20womens%20health%20gap%20a%201%20trillion%20dollar%20opportunity%20to%20improve%20lives%20and%20economies/gifs/pub-mhiwomenhealthgap-v16-ex13-lm-timed.gif" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h3>Investing in women’s health shows positive return on investment (ROI): for every $1 invested, approximately $3 is projected in economic growth</h3>
<p>Investing in improving women’s health not only improves women’s quality of life but also enables them to participate more actively in the workforce and make a living. The potential value created through women’s higher economic participation and productivity exceeds the costs of implementation by a ratio of $3 to $1 globally. This estimate is based on the net annual costs associated with the additional uptake of interventions required to address the women’s health gap, including all relevant interventions considered cost-effective in each setting.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2ae25155-0ef7-4c09-9beb-cb62f1ec93c0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">92</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2ae25155-0ef7-4c09-9beb-cb62f1ec93c0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">To identify the incremental or net steady-state cost of each intervention, we identified the cost per DALY averted from the scientific literature (primarily WHO, DCP-3, and the Tufts Cost-Effectiveness Analysis Registry) for each intervention and income archetype and converted to standardized US dollars. To calculate the total cost for each country, we multiplied the unit cost (cost per DALY averted) by the volume of DALYs averted by that particular intervention in 2040. For further discussion of the strengths and limitations of this approach, see the technical appendix.</span></span></span></a></span> The analysis compared this to the additional economic potential that could be unlocked by the health improvements associated with these interventions.</p>
<p>The expected economic return varies by region. The ROI is greatest in higher-income settings, where it is around $3.50 returned for every $1 invested. More investment is probably needed in some LICs to establish the basic health infrastructure required to support low-cost delivery of high-quality health services, as well as to create better and more rewarding economic opportunities for women. Still, the analysis indicates that the overall benefit would exceed the costs even in these settings, at a rate of around $2 returned on $1 invested.</p>
<p>The analysis examines only the direct costs of addressing the gaps in care delivery identified. In the longer term, a range of greater positive returns is possible, given that improvement in the lives of women influences the health and resilience of their families and communities.</p>
<h3>Where to start tackling the women’s health gap to reap the greatest benefit for all</h3>
<p>Globally, the top ten conditions by economic impact account for more than 50 percent of the total GDP impact. This highlights areas with high unmet needs and potential, aiding decision makers in prioritizing efforts to address health disparities. Specific conditions and their socioeconomic contexts vary among regions, influencing their contribution to the economy. This information could guide tailored strategies toward health equity.</p>
<p>The content and sequence of each action will need to be tailored to regional conditions. Building on the knowledge developed throughout this report, a fact-based strategic assessment can lead to better health equity for each country.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="dark" data-module-background="deep-blue" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="top-right" class="mck-o-edge-to-edge SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header___N7qG mck-c-module-wrapper"><style></style><div data-component="mdc-c-background-image" class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c background-image-section-header-DCE2C16DEF874F4381D80699A6E98697-bg SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__parallax-container__sgMMy" role="img" aria-label="Three friends, each of different ages and ethnic backgrounds, sharing joyful laughter together on a sofa." style="transform: translate(0px, 0px);"></div><div class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c mdc-c-bg-image--opaque-bg___CauU1_990311c" style="opacity:0.2"></div><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing"><div id="section-header-6" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper__CZEyB"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-positioned__fIWpF"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-sm SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-text__hSx1f" style="display: none; opacity: 0;"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__heading__2ePOu"><span>6. Call to action: How to close the women’s health gap</span></h2></div><div class="SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__section-holder__BaLti"></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>As noted in this report, women’s health has been under-researched, and women face different challenges from men in affordability and access to treatment. This health gap creates unnecessary suffering and preventable economic losses.</p>
<p>It does not have to be this way. Through collaborative efforts on five fronts, a more equitable and healthy future is possible. There is an opportunity to close the women’s health gap by (1) investing in women-centric R&D, (2) strengthening the collection and analysis of sex- and gender-disaggregated data, (3) enhancing access to gender-specific care, (4) encouraging investments in women’s health innovation, and (5) examining business policies to support women.</p>
<h3>Invest in women-centric research to fill the knowledge and data gaps in women-specific conditions, as well as in diseases affecting women differently and/or disproportionately</h3>
<p>The women’s health gap could be narrowed by increasing funding to achieve equality with investments in funding for men’s health and using protocols that set standards of equity and diversity. Scientists, life science companies (pharma, biotech, medtech), healthcare providers, and others in the healthcare ecosystem may consider how the traditional understanding of disease is focused primarily on the male body. A more in-depth understanding of these differences would enable more effective care interventions and improved health outcomes. One example of venture-capital-backed funding addressing this disparity is Repro Grants, which allots up to $100,000 for research projects aimed at deepening understanding of female reproductive biology.</p>
<p>For conditions that affect women differently or disproportionately, more effective interventions start with clinical trials designed with inclusivity at their core, informed by preclinical research using female animal models. Specifically, there should be stronger <a href="/bem/our-insights/accelerating-diversity-in-clinical-trials">diversity, equity, and inclusion guidelines for clinical trial design</a>. Guidance could incorporate male versus female disease prevalence mix and use sex-specific thresholds for biomarkers to yield an adequate patient representation in clinical trials.</p>
<p>Equitable representation by prevalence also implies more diverse research organizations. Life science companies, academic institutions, and educational bodies should ensure that women and people of color not only find representation but be actively involved in research, leadership, and decision-making roles. For example, women form almost 70 percent of the global health and social workforce, but it is estimated they hold only 25 percent of senior roles.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="bf0f2b71-961e-4868-9c67-d9581ead4a95"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">93</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="bf0f2b71-961e-4868-9c67-d9581ead4a95" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“10 key issues in ensuring gender equity in the global health workforce,” WHO, March 20, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span> The benefits of increasing women’s representation are manifold: for example, teams boasting diverse gender representation have been associated with higher levels of accountability and effectiveness.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d037f50a-2f8c-4c9d-ae25-95bb3f4d209a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">94</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d037f50a-2f8c-4c9d-ae25-95bb3f4d209a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Jennifer Asuako, “Women’s participation in decision making: Why it matters,” UN Development Programme, December 4, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> In one study that analyzed more than 440,000 medical patents filed from 1976 through to 2010, patented biomedical inventions created by women were up to 35 percent more likely to benefit women’s health than biomedical inventions created by men. The patents from women were more likely to address women-specific conditions such as breast cancer and postpartum preeclampsia, as well as conditions that disproportionately affect women, such as lupus.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="efcdf5d3-74cb-49b0-bf55-ce9551328f97"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">95</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="efcdf5d3-74cb-49b0-bf55-ce9551328f97" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Rembrand Koning, Sampsa Samila, and John-Paul Ferguson, “Who do we invent for? Patents by women focus more on women’s health, but few women get to invent,” <em>Science</em>, June 2021, Volume 372, Number 6548.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h3>Systematically collect and analyze sex-, ethnicity-, and gender-specific data to have more accurate representation of women’s health burden and the impact of different interventions</h3>
<p>The prevalence of conditions such as endometriosis and menopause is underestimated, leading investors and life science companies to underestimate the market potential of these conditions and underinvest. By accurately assessing and reporting on the prevalence of such conditions, national health institutes and other authorities may direct additional funding to the research and treatment of these underserved conditions.</p>
<ul>
    <li>Beyond epidemiological data, today’s technology makes the systematic collection and analysis of sex-, race-, and gender-disaggregated data simpler at all stages of the R&D process. Life science companies could harness this capability to strengthen the collection, analysis, and reporting of disaggregated data at each stage of the process. This approach to data has the potential to enable life sciences companies to evaluate the safety and efficacy of their pipeline products more accurately, including by adjusting formulations and dosages. This could yield better health outcomes and a higher probability of success. To further encourage the shift toward disaggregated data, the Women’s Health Innovation Opportunity Map 2023 proposes establishing sex as a biological variable.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e99d729e-81a1-444f-8a4f-b0e3adf64e4c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">96</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e99d729e-81a1-444f-8a4f-b0e3adf64e4c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Women's Health Innovation Opportunity Map: 50 high-return opportunities to advance global women’s health R&D</em>, Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation and National Institutes of Health, October 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> This would enable national health departments and international health organizations to develop and enforce guidelines regarding disaggregation of data by sex and gender in research studies and health surveys.</li>
    <li>Biotech, medtech, and FemTech enterprises also have exciting opportunities related to AI and ML, which ensures that these models do not exacerbate existing biases or violate patient privacy rules. Developing robust, secure, and holistic data sets could enable companies to differentiate in an overcrowded marketplace.</li>
</ul>
<h3>Enhance access to gender-specific care, from prevention to diagnosis and treatment</h3>
<ul>
    <li>Women deserve the same high-quality level of care from their healthcare providers as men, which doesn’t mean the same care per se. There is a pressing need to redesign medical curricula as well as residency and fellowships to reflect sex and gender differences. In addition to medical schools, continuing medical education organizations and credentialing entities could assess whether healthcare providers are receiving the latest information and training on the women’s health gap and sex- and gender-based differences. Current and future healthcare professionals of all specialties must be equipped with accurate and updated knowledge of biological differences, including sex-specific manifestations of symptoms. Future certification or tests could include questions meant to address whether providers have internalized this knowledge.</li>
    <li>Next, the path to excellence in clinical care lies in acknowledging and rectifying inherent equity disparities. Gender- and sex-responsive services benefit patients, healthcare providers, and society at large. Health systems could implement new guidelines and protocols (for example, sex-specific cutoffs for biomarkers, discharge checklists) to guide decision making and minimize biases. Similarly, life science companies could include sex-specific evidence and outcomes on product package inserts and labels to inform healthcare professionals on the best regimens for different subpopulations.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="23a75107-6622-4065-a3b7-8915910263de"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">97</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="23a75107-6622-4065-a3b7-8915910263de" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Women's Health Innovation Opportunity Map: 50 high-return opportunities to advance global women’s health R&D</em>, Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation and National Institutes of Health, October 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li>To reduce maternal mortality globally, investing in the training and upskilling of midwives could save an estimated 4.3 million lives per year and prevent roughly two-thirds of maternal deaths, 64 percent of newborn deaths, and 65 percent of stillbirths while contributing to the economic development and empowerment of women.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2ad41884-ff4b-4e0b-9e2c-e26c21007a0c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">98</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2ad41884-ff4b-4e0b-9e2c-e26c21007a0c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Christina Östberg Lloyd and Christian Sand Horup, “Leaders in women's health call for more investment in midwives to prevent 4.3 million deaths each year,” World Economic Forum, May 5, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li>Governments, educational bodies, philanthropic institutions, and many other stakeholders can use this moment to raise awareness of the sex-specific manifestations of disease—for example, ensuring that newly diagnosed endometriosis patients have access to up-to-date resources, including which trials they could potentially participate in. Healthcare entities, philanthropic organizations, or community health workers could start or reinvigorate in-person support groups for conditions such as endometriosis or menopause or for mental health support. Collectively, better education and resources, plus new diagnostics, are among the ways to potentially elevate the quality of healthcare women receive.</li>
</ul>
<p>In addition, two things to enable closing the gap include:</p>
<h3>Create incentives for new financing models to close the women’s health gap</h3>
<ul>
    <li>Historically, given lower levers of investments overall for women’s health under the traditional financing model schemes, new financing models have a critical role to play. These models can accelerate innovation. One example is the advance market commitment (AMC) geared to COVID-19 vaccine development and deployment.</li>
    <li>Research and reliable data on the women’s health landscape can help spur investment. For investors, the gender-based healthcare landscape presents a mosaic of unexplored opportunities. By pivoting toward this opportunity, investors can channel funds into high-impact areas, bridge the data gap, and enable more investment and innovation.</li>
    <li>Governments could explore policies that encourage sex- and gender-responsive health research and services—for example, by earmarking funds, providing tax incentives, lowering application fees, and expediting the drug approval process. Philanthropic organizations, donors, and international bodies could offer grants and prizes at a national or local level to spur innovation while supporting capacity building in regions where gender-based health disparities are highest. Examples might be launching a grant or award program geared toward reducing rates of respiratory illnesses in areas where there is a high percentage of women smokers, or toward a technology-based solution for women in vulnerable populations to access transportation to healthcare services.</li>
    <li>Private-sector stakeholders could help develop new financial products and investment vehicles, such as gender-lens investing, to attract capital to projects that directly address the women’s health gap. Governments could further promote private-sector investments by creating tax incentive programs for angel investors and venture capitalists that invest in women’s health.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="383341ce-2eca-4b7b-892a-3c10d58d5045"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">99</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="383341ce-2eca-4b7b-892a-3c10d58d5045" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Women's Health Innovation Opportunity Map: 50 high-return opportunities to advance global women’s health R&D</em>, Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation and National Institutes of Health, October 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li>With collaboration, stakeholders have the potential to encourage investments and inspire the development of innovative financing models in women’s health.</li>
</ul>
<h3>Establish business policies that support women’s health</h3>
<p>As previously outlined, healthcare disparities also lead to economic losses due to absenteeism, presenteeism, and reduced productivity overall. Employers could consider how their workplace policies and benefits support women’s health, examine ways to better involve women in decision-making processes, provide health and wellness benefits that support women’s health, and create safe working environments in which women can speak openly about their health needs. By better understanding employee demographics, employers could invest in the areas with higher impact and potential. For example, if a workforce includes women between 45 and 55 years old, high impact could come from flexible work policies that recognize menopause. Given the fact that women are more than twice as likely as men to have depressive symptoms in their lifetime,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="49b1be57-511c-4b4f-9b42-81e2eed83339"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">100</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="49b1be57-511c-4b4f-9b42-81e2eed83339" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Depression in women,” Mental Health America, n.d.</span></span></span></a></span> employers may explore how mental-health programs can help employees find evidence-based mental health resources that meet their needs.</p>
<p>Often, leaders create change in the workplace based on their own experiences, knowledge, or vision. If the decision makers are predominantly men, the workplace tends to benefit men. Previous McKinsey research has found a “broken rung” in women’s advancement throughout industries: for every 100 men promoted from entry-level to manager roles, 87 women are promoted and only 73 women of color are promoted.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2e5cba0b-9b1d-4399-84bf-a43e91accc10"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">101</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2e5cba0b-9b1d-4399-84bf-a43e91accc10" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“<a href="/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/women-in-the-workplace-2023">Women in the workplace 2023</a>,” McKinsey, October 5, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Overall, due to gender disparities in early promotions, men end up with 60 percent of manager-level positions in a typical company. More women in senior leadership positions may be able to advocate for policies that support women’s health, and companies may ultimately benefit from a healthier and more productive workforce.</p>
<p>Data-driven, scalable actions to improve women’s health may vary widely, but the critical component is to determine how each stakeholder can contribute to narrowing the gap.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="dark" data-module-background="deep-blue" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="top-right" class="mck-o-edge-to-edge SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header___N7qG mck-c-module-wrapper"><style></style><div data-component="mdc-c-background-image" class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c background-image-section-header-23E4651CB4AF43399B7883F43A74D2C4-bg SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__parallax-container__sgMMy" role="img" aria-label="A Muslim woman doctor wearing a lab coat, hijab, and stethoscope, sitting at her desk with a welcoming gaze towards the camera." style="transform: translate(0px, 0px);"></div><div class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c mdc-c-bg-image--opaque-bg___CauU1_990311c" style="opacity:0.4"></div><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing"><div id="section-header-7" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper__CZEyB"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-positioned__fIWpF"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-sm SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-text__hSx1f" style="display: none; opacity: 0;"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__heading__2ePOu"><span>Conclusion</span></h2></div><div class="SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__section-holder__BaLti"></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>If health equity efforts sit within a tree of principles, they can be watered by research, flourish in the sun of business investments, and grow far-reaching branches that stretch into the economy.</p>
<p>Achieving health equity is a collaborative and ongoing endeavor that relies on the active participation of governments, healthcare institutions, nongovernmental organizations, individuals, and all stakeholders vested in this cause. Tackling the women’s health gap depends on addressing the interconnected factors outlined in this report: the deficit of women-specific knowledge in science, the glaring data gaps, the disparities in healthcare delivery, and the insufficient investment in women’s health.</p>
<p>Recognizing the vast potential to improve the lives and livelihoods of half the global population while boosting the economy serves as the catalyst for closing the women’s health gap. Every facet of this gap, from limited education to suboptimal treatments, offers an opportunity for transformation with the active involvement of governments, life science innovators, educational institutions, philanthropists, activists, and more.</p>
<p>In this endeavor lies an opportunity of $1 trillion in economic potential driven by improved women’s health and economic participation. The question is not whether this wealth of opportunities exists but rather who will take the initiative to seize it and drive change.</p>
<p>Women’s health is not a stand-alone issue; it is a cornerstone of societal well-being and progress. Better health and well-being for women creates a ripple effect that extends to families, communities, and nations. This holistic approach, supported by collective action and sustained investment, will not only narrow the health gap but also contribute to the betterment of a shared global future.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong><a href="/our-people/kweilin-ellingrud">Kweilin Ellingrud</a></strong> is a senior partner in McKinsey’s Minneapolis office and a director of the McKinsey Global Institute. <strong><a href="/our-people/lucy-perez">Lucy Pérez</a></strong> is a senior partner in the Boston office and an affiliated leader of the McKinsey Health Institute. <strong><a href="/our-people/anouk-petersen">Anouk Petersen</a></strong> is a partner in the Geneva office. <strong><a href="/our-people/valentina-sartori">Valentina Sartori</a></strong> is a partner in the Zurich office.</p>

Card_content-block__pF6Z1"><span>Article</span><h6 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-6"><a data-component="mdc-c-link"
