current on your favorite topics"}}}]},"articlesidebar":{"results":[{"mediaID":{"value":"1"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eThis report reflects women\u0026rsquo;s health as a market segment. The authors acknowledge the importance of healthcare to the transgender, nonbinary, and gender-fluid communities and that not all people who identify as women are born biologically female.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe authors have often used the term \u0026ldquo;sex and gender\u0026rdquo; to reflect inclusive language and recognize the need for future research into health issues that is inclusive of the transgender, nonbinary, and gender-fluid communities. They also acknowledge the profound differences for women based on factors such as race, ethnicity, socioeconomic status, disability, age, and sexual orientation. Additional work and research should reflect on how to tackle these barriers alongside the overall women\u0026rsquo;s health gap.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn this report, the term \u0026ldquo;woman\u0026rdquo; includes those under age 18.\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Terminology used in this report"}},"footnotes":{"value":""},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"2"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAssessment of the women\u0026rsquo;s health gap and the potential to reduce it\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnalysts used the Global Burden of Disease data from the University of Washington\u0026rsquo;s Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (IHME) to forecast disease burdens up to 2040. (The IHME Global Burden of Disease looks at mortality and disability, quantifying health loss from hundreds of diseases, injuries, and risk factors.) The forecast includes diseases leading to death and poor health conditions such as infectious diseases and chronic conditions. Analysts quantified this health gap in terms of disability-adjusted life years (DALYs) and the extent to which this difference results from the structural and systematic barriers women face. DALYs for a disease or health condition are the sum of the years of life lost (YLLs) due to premature mortality and the years lived with a disability (YLDs) due to prevalent cases of the disease or health condition in a population.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo gauge how much the disease burden could be reduced, McKinsey thoroughly reviewed clinical evidence for the top 64 diseases affecting women, which account for nearly 86 percent of the global disease burden.[[footnote 1]] This review focused on around 180 interventions, based on guidelines from leading institutions such as the World Health Organization (WHO) and journals such as \u003cem\u003eThe Lancet\u003c/em\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor each intervention related to the 64 diseases, McKinsey examined the following factors:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eidentification of potential reduction of morbidity and mortality,[[footnote 2]] scaled up to all diseases, considering the differences between men and women to identify the women\u0026rsquo;s health gap\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eprojection of total population and working population baselines with the expansion from health interventions and labor force capacity interventions\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eestimation of the duration to realize the full benefits, considering implementation time and the lag before health benefits appear\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCases with limited adoption data and correlated assumptions are detailed in the technical appendix.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eQuantification of the economic impact\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo determine the potential economic effects of the proposed health interventions, analysts used population and labor force predictions up to 2040.[[footnote 3]] These health gains were converted into labor force involvement, productivity, and economic gains through four avenues: fewer early deaths, fewer health conditions, extended economic capacity to contribute, and increased productivity. The assumptions for estimating the impacts were based on academic studies and verified by experts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis analysis acknowledges:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eDisease burden evolution.\u003c/em\u003e McKinsey does not forecast disease and acknowledges that unexpected events such as COVID-19 can change projections. The IHME\u0026rsquo;s disease burden data reflects the best available data.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eIntervention effectiveness.\u003c/em\u003e Given that evolving scientific evidence may be inconclusive, the research included input from academic and clinical experts.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eFuture innovations.\u003c/em\u003e McKinsey focused on advanced-stage technologies and consulted field experts.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eAddressing the women\u0026rsquo;s health gap.\u003c/em\u003e Analysts assumed that if existing interventions are more effective for or more frequently adopted by men, the same rates could be achieved for women. If gender-based efficacy wasn\u0026rsquo;t monitored, the analysis assumed a similar gender gap to the ones for which data was available.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eEconomic implications.\u003c/em\u003e The economic analysis makes assumptions about labor market choices\u0026mdash;for instance, how age and health affect labor force participation. Evidence such as current labor force statistics and potential labor market changes were considered.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eData gap.\u003c/em\u003e Undercounting and undervaluing of diseases and their health burden on women likely leads to an underestimation of the women\u0026rsquo;s health gap, both in health and monetary terms. Therefore, the true gap will likely surpass all estimates presented in this report.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Research methodology"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eMeasured in disability-adjusted life years (DALYs), comprising years lived with disability (YLDs) and years of life lost (YLLs).\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eReduction per country, age group, disease, risk factor, year analyzed; measured in deaths, years lived with disability (YLDs), and years of life lost (YLLs).\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;Global Burden of Disease Study 2019 (GBD 2019)\u0026rdquo; IHME; \u003cem\u003eILO labour force estimates and projections: 1990\u0026ndash;2030\u003c/em\u003e, International Labour Organization, November 2017.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"3"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eThe race to develop a COVID-19 vaccine required a massive number of experimental and observational clinical trials. Representation of women was equal to that of men (or better) across trials, but this was not reflected in consistent reporting of sex-specific results. One analysis examined 41 articles on COVID-19 research, of which 35 articles showed safety data, but only 12 of these presented data by sex or gender.[[footnote 1]] In a review of 2,500 COVID-19 studies, less than 5 percent of investigators had planned for sex-disaggregated data analysis in their studies.[[footnote 2]] In studies for which adverse effects and sex differences were published, adverse events were more common in women patients.[[footnote 3]]\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Case study: COVID-19 vaccine development"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eAmy Vassallo et al., \u0026ldquo;Sex and gender in COVID-19 vaccine research: Substantial evidence gaps remain,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eFrontiers in Global Women\u0026rsquo;s Health\u003c/em\u003e, November 2021, Volume 2.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eLavanya Vijayasingham et al., \u0026ldquo;Sex-disaggregated data in COVID-19 vaccine trials,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eLancet\u003c/em\u003e, March 2021, Volume 397.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eVassallo et al., \u0026ldquo;Sex and gender in COVID-19 vaccine research,\u0026rdquo; November 2021.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"4"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eThis paper explores ways in which sex and gender influence an individual\u0026rsquo;s health chances and experience of health services. These differences are all too often exacerbated by overlapping levels of discrimination and disadvantage, such as race, ethnicity, socioeconomic status, disability, age, and sexual orientation. The effects are strikingly clear in maternal health (exhibit). Within the United States, Native American and Black women are up to four times more likely to die from a pregnancy-related cause than White women. For Black families, this holds true even after adjustment for differences in income levels.[[footnote 1]] In India, a woman of upper caste is three times more likely to use prenatal care and five times more likely to have a trained birth attendant than a woman of lower caste.[[footnote 2]] A study in the United Kingdom indicated that women from ethnic minority backgrounds have an increased risk of postpartum hemorrhage.[[footnote 3]] On a global scale, 94 percent of pregnancy-related deaths occurred in low‐resource settings, with 86 percent occurring in sub‐Saharan Africa and Southern Asia.[[footnote 4]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit sb4]]"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Intersectionality and health outcomes"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eKate Kennedy-Moulton et al., \u003cem\u003eMaternal and infant health inequality: New evidence from linked administrative data\u003c/em\u003e, NBER Working Paper 30093, 2022.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eE. Saroha, M. Altarac, and L. M. Sibley, \u0026ldquo;Caste and maternal health care service use among rural Hindu women in Maitha, Uttar Pradesh, India,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eJournal of Midwifery \u0026amp; Women's Health\u003c/em\u003e, 2008, Volume 53.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eJennifer Jardine et al., \u0026ldquo;Risk of postpartum haemorrhage is associated with ethnicity: A cohort study of 981,801 births in England,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eBJOG: An International Journal of Obstetrics and Gynaecology\u003c/em\u003e, December 2021, Volume 129, Number 8.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;Maternal health,\u0026rdquo; Pan American Health Organization, n.d.; \u003cem\u003eTrends in maternal mortality, 2000 to 2017: Estimates by WHO, UNICEF, UNFPA, World Bank Group, and the United Nations Population Division\u003c/em\u003e, United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA), September 2019.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"5"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eGlobally, 190 million women are suffering from endometriosis.[[footnote 1]] Currently, no cure exists, and treatments focus on symptom management. Based on prevalence and unmet need, the market potential for endometriosis treatments is estimated at $180 billion to $250 billion globally (exhibit), given today\u0026rsquo;s share of endometriosis patients seeking treatment. Innovation in this space, including faster diagnosis rates and earlier access to treatment, could increase the market potential.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit sb5]]\n\u003cp\u003eMenopause is another area of high unmet need globally. Based on the age distribution of the population and share of symptomatic cases, it is estimated that more than 450 million women worldwide have menopausal or perimenopausal symptoms.[[footnote 2]] Based on the prevalence of menopause, its impact on women\u0026rsquo;s life, the high unmet need, and the share of women seeking treatment today, estimated global market potential to treat symptoms ranges from $120 billion to $350 billion globally.[[footnote 3]]\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Market potential of treatments for endometriosis and menopause"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;Endometriosis,\u0026rdquo; World Health Organization, March 24, 2023.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eEstimate based on global population of women between ages 45 and 55 and more than 90 percent of women experiencing at least one symptom during the menopausal transition.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eAja Mangum, \u0026ldquo;The $600 billion market for women in menopause is fit for disruption,\u0026rdquo; Bloomberg, March 28, 2021.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"6"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eMenopause and endometriosis not only cause women pain and reduce their quality of life but also substantially affect their ability to work and their earning potential. Roughly 80 percent of affected women state that menopause interferes with their lives, and one-third of these women also experience depression.[[footnote 1]] Further, menopause is linked to premature departure from the workforce.[[footnote 2]] Similarly, endometriosis is linked to loss in productivity and absenteeism.[[footnote 3]] This analysis factors in the actual economic impact for both conditions. Studies have found that up to 90 percent of women reported menopausal symptoms during the transition.[[footnote 4]] This leads to a global prevalence of more than 450 million women and highlights the vast underestimate (versus 35 million in the IHME database). For endometriosis, IHME places the number of cases at 24 million, whereas the WHO puts the prevalence at 190 million.[[footnote 5]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBased on these adjusted numbers, improving effectiveness, uptake, access, and delivery of care for these conditions alone could give a $130 billion uplift to the global economy by 2040 (exhibit).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit sb6]]"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Endometriosis and menopause have a substantial impact on women’s ability to work and earning potential"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eBurns et al., \u0026ldquo;Closing the data gaps in women\u0026rsquo;s health,\u0026rdquo; April 3, 2023.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eLizzy Burden, \u0026ldquo;Women are leaving the workforce for a little-talked-about reason,\u0026rdquo; Bloomberg, June 18, 2021; S. D\u0026rsquo;Angelo et al., \u0026ldquo;Impact of menopausal symptoms on work: Findings from women in the Health and Employment after Fifty (HEAF) study,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eInternational Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health\u003c/em\u003e, December 2022, Volume 20, Number 1.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eKelechi E.
